question_details.title: Will Blue Ghost successfully land on the moon before April 1, 2025?
question_details.description: The mission's planned landing date [is](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blue_Ghost_Mission_1) March 2, 2025.
question_details.resolution_criteria: This question resolves as **Yes** if [Blue Ghost Mission 1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blue_Ghost_Mission_1) successfully lands on the moon.
question_details.fine_print: For the purposes of this question, a successful landing will be defined as one which results in the lander remaining intact and able to communicate with the Earth, and which does not prevent at least some of its payload from being able to carry out its intended mission. For example, a landing that resulted in minor damage to the lander, its systems, or some of its payload, but some of the carried payload/equipment was still able to carry out its intended mission and communicate with Earth, would result in the question resolving as Yes (this does not include cases where the lander is destroyed on impact but payloads such as time capsules might survive impact)

news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Blue Ghost Captures Stunning Moon Footage Ahead of Historic Landing**
Firefly Aerospace's Blue Ghost lander has captured stunning footage of the Moon's far side as it prepares for a historic landing. The lander, carrying 10 science and technology instruments for NASA, will descend into Mare Crisium, a large impact basin on the lunar near side, on March 2. The mission aims to assess longer-term lunar habitability prospects, including the possibility of a permanent Moon base. Blue Ghost's descent will be controlled using thrusters, as there is no atmosphere to provide natural drag. If successful, the lander will operate its science payload for 14 Earth days, capturing a solar eclipse and a lunar sunset, before shutting down forever. 'The radiator panels are moving nominally to protect Blue Ghost's subsystems from extreme temperatures,' the company wrote on its live blog. 'The video below, sped up by 10X, was taken about 100 km above the lunar surface, showing the far side of the Moon and a top-down view of Blue Ghost's RCS thrusters (center) and radiator panels on each side.'
Original language: en
Publish date: February 28, 2025 12:54 AM
Source:[ScienceAlert](https://www.sciencealert.com/blue-ghost-captures-stunning-moon-footage-ahead-of-historic-landing)

**Blue Ghost Spacecraft Captures Rare Images of Earth Eclipsing the Moon**
The Blue Ghost spacecraft, created by Firefly Aerospace, has shared a treasure trove of photographs from its recent mission to the Moon's orbit, including a stunning selfie with the Earth eclipsing the Moon in the background. The spacecraft, launched on January 15, captured impressive images of the Earth and Moon during its mission. It is now in orbit and is scheduled to land on March 2. Blue Ghost carries 10 scientific instruments that will help study the lunar surface, measure electric and magnetic fields, and test new technologies. This spacecraft is part of NASA's program where private companies are exploring the Moon. On its way to the Moon, the spacecraft took several photos, including a selfie of the Earth. One of the most striking images shows the Earth eclipsing the Moon, creating a breathtaking view that is rarely captured. Blue Ghost reached the Moon's orbit on February 13. If the landing is successful, it will become the second private spacecraft to make a soft landing on the Moon, following the Odysseus module from Intuitive Machines, which landed in February 2024. The landing site for Blue Ghost is the Mare Crisium crater, an ancient impact crater partially filled with basaltic lava. The spacecraft also captured the far side of the Moon, which is not visible from Earth. As for the history of space exploration, the first images of the Earth from space were taken in 1946 using a V-2 rocket launched from New Mexico, USA, which reached an altitude of around 105 km and took several black-and-white photos of the planet. The first images of the Moon's surface were obtained in 1959 by the Soviet spacecraft 'Luna-1', and more detailed images were seen in 1966 by 'Luna-9', which successfully landed on the Moon's surface. After landing, Blue Ghost will conduct a series of experiments, studying the composition of the soil and properties of lunar dust. These data will help scientists better understand the history of the Moon and prepare technologies for future missions. The spacecraft has already shared stunning images, and more scientific discoveries are ahead.
Original language: ru
Publish date: February 27, 2025 03:13 PM
Source:[Почта@Mail.ru](https://hi-tech.mail.ru/news/123344-kosmicheskij-apparat-blue-ghost-zapechatlel-redkie-vidy-zatmeniya-zemli-lunoj/)

**Spacecraft beams back stunning moon video before ambitious landing**
Firefly Aerospace's Blue Ghost spacecraft is set to land on the moon's near side on March 2, as part of NASA's Commercial Lunar Payload Services program. The spacecraft has shared a stunning video of the moon's surface before its descent, showcasing the 'magnificent desolation' witnessed by NASA astronaut Buzz Aldrin in 1969. The 6.6-foot-tall lander is carrying a suite of instruments and experiments for NASA, including radiation-tolerant computing tests and sampling of the lunar regolith. Landing on the moon remains a daunting task due to its lack of atmosphere, but Firefly Aerospace is confident in its ability to successfully land the spacecraft. If all goes as planned, the Blue Ghost will perform science operations for 14 days after landing, and human spaceflight is expected to follow these robotic missions, with NASA planning to fly astronauts to the moon in mid-2027. 'That feeling you get when you look out the window and realize you're almost home! T-4 days until we land [on] the Moon,' Firefly Aerospace posted on X on Feb. 26. 
Original language: en
Publish date: February 27, 2025 10:30 AM
Source:[Mashable](https://mashable.com/article/moon-spacecraft-blue-ghost-firefly-footage)

**'The Moon Is So Close':  Firefly's Blue Ghost Captures Breathtaking Visuals Of Cratered Lunar Surface**
Firefly Aerospace's Blue Ghost spacecraft has captured breathtaking visuals of the lunar surface from approximately 100 km above. The visuals provide a detailed view of the Moon's cratered surface. The Blue Ghost is set to land at Mare Crisium on the near side of the Moon on March 2. According to NASA, 'The Moon is so close, we can taste it! New footage from @Firefly_Space shows their lunar lander's view from 60 miles (100 km) above the Moon.' This mission is part of NASA's Commercial Lunar Payload Services (CLPS) initiative, supporting three missions to the Moon in 2025, 2026, and 2028.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 27, 2025 09:26 AM
Source:[Free Press Journal](https://www.freepressjournal.in/science/the-moon-is-so-close-fireflys-blue-ghost-captures-breathtaking-visuals-of-cratered-lunar-surface)

**Blue Ghost Mission Prepares for Lunar Descent**
Firefly Aerospace's Blue Ghost mission is preparing for a lunar descent on March 2, which could make the company the second private corporation to successfully land on the Moon. The mission carries 10 scientific instruments from NASA, part of the Commercial Lunar Payload Services project, which aims to prepare for human return to the Moon through private companies. The Blue Ghost spacecraft, capable of carrying 155 kg of payload, was launched on January 15 and entered lunar orbit on February 13. After two additional orbital corrections, the spacecraft is now in a circular orbit, preparing for the lunar descent. The landing site is near the Mons Latreille volcanic formation, and the instruments will conduct scientific operations for about a day lunar (14 days on Earth). The mission will study the lunar regolith, including its adhesive properties, and will test new technologies for collecting and analyzing samples. The spacecraft will also capture images of the lunar eclipse on March 14. According to NASA, the mission aims to improve the precision of lunar navigation, validate new technologies for collecting and analyzing samples, and study the lunar regolith. 'We are excited to see the progress of this mission,' said a NASA official. 'It will help us to better understand the Moon and prepare for future human missions.'
Original language: es
Publish date: February 27, 2025 06:52 AM
Source:[LaVanguardia](https://www.lavanguardia.com/ciencia/20250227/10422463/cuenta-segundo-alunizaje-privado-historia.html)

**Intuitive Machines Prepares for Second Attempt to Land on the Moon**
Intuitive Machines is preparing for its second attempt to land on the Moon after a historic but not entirely successful first flight. The company has improved navigation and equipment to increase the chances of a successful landing. The Athena mission is expected to land on the Moon's Mons-Munon plateau on March 6, closer to the southern pole than any previous lunar mission. On board, there is scientific equipment, including a drill to search for ice beneath the surface and a jumping drone named Grace, named after scientist Grace Hopper. The drone can navigate the complex lunar terrain with its slopes, boulders, and craters, which could be valuable for future manned missions. Additionally, a small rover will test the lunar cellular network provided by Nokia Bell Labs for transmitting commands, images, and video between the landing module, rover, and drone. However, the main challenge remains achieving a perfect landing, which the company failed to achieve with its first landing module Odysseus in February 2024. General Director Trent Martin acknowledged the difficulties and stated that the company has made key improvements, including upgrading the cable system of the laser altimeter, which provides data on height and speed and helps choose a safe landing site. The coordination with NASA's deep space communication network has also been improved for more accurate navigation. The arrival of Athena on the Moon on March 2 is expected to be preceded by the landing of another private American spacecraft, Blue Ghost from Firefly Aerospace, launched in January. Additionally, a NASA Lunar Trailblazer probe will be launched on the same rocket, which will enter orbit after a four-month journey and begin a two-year mission to study the distribution of various forms of water on the Moon. 'We've made significant improvements to our landing technology, including the laser altimeter and our communication systems,' said Trent Martin, CEO of Intuitive Machines. 'We're confident that we can achieve a successful landing this time around.'
Original language: ru
Publish date: February 26, 2025 06:55 PM
Source:[iXBT.com](https://www.ixbt.com/news/2025/02/26/intuitive-machines-gotovitsja-ko-vtoroj-popytke-posadki-na-lunu.html)

**Lunar lander captures stunning views of moon ahead of descent: See images taken by Blue Ghost**
The Blue Ghost lunar lander, operated by Firefly Aerospace, has captured stunning views of the moon's far side as it prepares to land on the moon's surface. The lander, which entered lunar orbit on February 13, has traveled 2.2 million miles and has all 10 payloads for NASA 'remain healthy,' according to Firefly. The lander will attempt to land on the moon's near side on March 2 at 3:45 a.m. EST, near a volcanic feature called Mons Latreille. The landing site is within Mare Crisium, a 300-mile-wide basin that is believed to have been created by early volcanic eruptions and flooded with basaltic lava more than 3 billion years ago. Firefly's spacecraft is on a mission to deliver and help test a fleet of NASA's scientific instruments to study the moon's environment before humans return. The instruments will be put to use for a complete lunar day, equivalent to about 14 Earth days, and will provide insights into how space weather and other cosmic forces affect Earth. Blue Ghost also plans to capture high-definition imagery of a total eclipse as the Earth blocks the sun just before a lunar sunset on March 16. 'The view is of the moon's far side, an area not visible to Earth, and shows our planet rising and setting behind the celestial body,' said Firefly in an update on its blog. 'The Blue Ghost lander documented the stunning sight amid maneuvers to get the spacecraft closer and closer to the lunar surface ahead of a landing attempt planned for the early hours of Sunday, March 2.'
Original language: en
Publish date: February 26, 2025 05:45 PM
Source:[Yahoo](https://ca.news.yahoo.com/lunar-lander-captures-stunning-views-173810688.html)

**Spacecraft swoops around moon to prepare for landing, snaps footage**
The Blue Ghost spacecraft, operated by Firefly Aerospace, has successfully completed its third and final lunar orbit maneuver, preparing for a landing on the moon's near side on March 2. The mission, funded by NASA, will attempt to touch down in Mare Crisium, a lava-covered basin. Firefly Aerospace released footage of the maneuver, with the company stating, 'Earth rise, Earth set, repeat! Blue Ghost's third and final lunar orbit maneuver is complete!' The mission is carrying a suite of instruments and experiments for NASA, including radiation-tolerant computing tests and sampling of the lunar regolith. However, landing on the moon remains a challenge, with recent U.S. commercial spacecraft experiencing difficulties. NASA plans to land astronauts on the moon in mid-2027, where they will spend a week exploring the south pole and accessing lunar water.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 26, 2025 05:12 PM
Source:[Yahoo](https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/spacecraft-swoops-around-moon-prepare-100000463.html)

**Blue Ghost Lunar Lander to Attempt Historic Landing on March 2**
The Blue Ghost lander, developed by Firefly Aerospace, is set to attempt a lunar landing on March 2, near the Mare Crisium on the visible side of the Moon. According to Firefly Aerospace, the lander will perform a 19-second engine burn to enter its descent trajectory. The mission, Blue Ghost 1, is part of the NASA's Commercial Lunar Payload Services program, which aims to send private missions to the Moon. Blue Ghost will carry 10 payloads, including the Lunar GNSS Receiver Experiment (LuGRE), developed in collaboration with the Italian Space Agency, to study the possibility of using terrestrial satellite positioning systems on the Moon. If successful, Blue Ghost will remain operational for two weeks or one lunar day, conducting experiments to study lunar dust, a critical environmental factor for long-term human presence on the Moon. The lunar landing will be broadcast live by NASA, starting 45 minutes before contact with the surface, on NASA and Firefly Aerospace channels.
Original language: it
Publish date: February 25, 2025 04:33 PM
Source:[dday.it](https://www.dday.it/redazione/52171/il-2-marzo-occhi-puntati-sulla-luna-blue-ghost-di-firefly-tentera-lallunaggio)

**Blue Ghost Spacecraft Successfully Enters New Orbit Around the Moon**
The Blue Ghost spacecraft has successfully entered a new orbit around the Moon, marking a significant step in its 45-day journey to the lunar surface. The spacecraft's engines were fired for 3 minutes and 18 seconds on February 18, allowing it to transition from a high, elliptical orbit to a lower orbit about 120 km (75 miles) above the Moon's surface. From this new location, Blue Ghost captured new images of the far side of the Moon and transmitted them back to Earth. Although this maneuver is crucial for preparing the spacecraft for its planned landing on March 2, it comes with challenges, including periods of temporary communication loss between the spacecraft and the control team in Texas. During the long journey that began on January 15, the team was able to calibrate the instruments on board. Blue Ghost will use its 10 scientific instruments to analyze the lunar heat flow, measure the magnetic and electric fields on the surface, and study the chemical composition of the lunar regolith. The spacecraft will also test technologies that could contribute to NASA's Artemis mission, which aims to send humans to the Moon. 'Blue Ghost' is not a direct flight from Kennedy Space Center to the Moon, but rather a journey that included several weeks in orbit around Earth after launch. During this time, the spacecraft's cameras captured stunning images of our planet. Blue Ghost is the latest private spacecraft attempting to land on the Moon, following previous successes and failures. In April 2023, the Japanese company's Hakuto-R M1 spacecraft crashed during its landing attempt. In January 2024, the Astrobotic Perseverance spacecraft failed in its mission after launch. However, in February 2024, the Intuitive Machines' Odyssey spacecraft successfully landed, despite suffering a leg break. If Blue Ghost successfully lands safely, it will soon be joined by the Intuitive Machines' Resilience spacecraft, which was launched on the same Falcon 9 rocket. The Resilience spacecraft is expected to attempt a landing in May or June, carrying the robot Tenacious to explore the lunar regolith. Intuitive Machines is also planning to launch another mission next week, featuring a robot capable of jumping on the lunar surface to explore a permanently dark crater.
Original language: ar
Publish date: February 20, 2025 11:43 AM
Source:[RT Arabic](https://arabic.rt.com/space/1648263-%D8%A8%D9%84%D9%88-%D8%BA%D9%88%D8%B3%D8%AA-%D9%85%D8%B4%D9%87%D8%AF%D8%A7-%D9%86%D8%A7%D8%AF%D8%B1%D8%A7-%D9%84%D9%84%D8%AC%D8%A7%D9%86%D8%A8-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A8%D8%B9%D9%8A%D8%AF-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%82%D9%85%D8%B1-%D8%A8%D8%AD%D8%B1-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A3%D8%B2%D9%85%D8%A7%D8%AA/)

**Blue Ghost Lunar Lander Makes Historic Images of the Moon's Far Side**
The Blue Ghost lunar lander, developed by Firefly Aerospace, has successfully progressed towards its goal. Launched on January 15, 2025, using a Falcon 9 rocket, the lander entered a high elliptical orbit around the Moon on February 13. On February 18, at 3:09 AM EST, Blue Ghost conducted a three-minute maneuver, moving to a lower orbit and approaching the surface at a distance of 120 km. From this position, the lander made new images of the Moon's far side and transmitted them back to Earth. This maneuver prepared Blue Ghost for its planned March 2 landing in the Mare Crisium region, a lunar basin formed by an ancient asteroid impact and filled with basaltic lava. The lander carries 10 scientific instruments to analyze the thermal flow from the Moon's interior, study the magnetic and electric fields on the surface, and determine the chemical composition of the lunar regolith. The mission will also test technologies that could be used in NASA's Artemis program, aimed at returning humans to the Moon. This phase allowed the onboard instruments to be calibrated before further travel. Previous private attempts at lunar landing have had mixed results. In April 2023, the Japanese Hakuto-R M1 lander, developed by ispace, crashed during its landing attempt. In January 2024, the American Peregrine lander, developed by Astrobotic, also failed, crashing shortly after launch. However, in February 2024, the Odysseus lander, developed by Intuitive Machines, successfully landed, albeit with a damaged leg. If Blue Ghost's landing is successful, it will be a significant achievement for private space missions. A Japanese lander, Resilience, developed by ispace, is expected to land soon, with a planned launch in May or June 2025. It will carry a rover, Tenacious, designed to study the lunar regolith in the far north of the Moon.
Original language: ru
Publish date: February 20, 2025 09:48 AM
Source:[Рамблер](https://news.rambler.ru/tech/54234933-blue-ghost-sdelal-redkie-snimki-obratnoy-storony-luny-video/)

**Private Lunar Lander Blue Ghost Successfully Enters Orbit Around the Moon**
The private lunar lander Blue Ghost, developed by Firefly Aerospace, has successfully entered into orbit around the Moon after a nearly month-long spaceflight. The lander, which is scheduled to attempt a landing on the Moon's surface on March 2, has captured stunning images of the Moon's surface using its cameras. The images show the Moon's surface, covered in craters, and were taken from a close distance. Blue Ghost was launched on a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket on January 15 and is carrying 10 scientific and technological experiments for NASA. The experiments aim to better understand the local environment and prepare for a human mission to the Moon in 2027. If the landing is successful, it will be a historic achievement, as only one private lander has successfully landed on the Moon before, Intuitive Machines' lander in February 2024. Another private lander, Resilience, developed by ispace, is also on its way to the Moon, but with a longer trajectory and no scientific experiments for NASA. 'This is a significant step towards a human mission to the Moon in 2027,' said NASA officials. 'We are excited to see the results of the experiments and the images captured by Blue Ghost.'
Original language: uk
Publish date: February 16, 2025 07:59 AM
Source:[focus.ua](https://focus.ua/uk/technologies/693858-privatniy-posadkoviy-modul-dosyag-misyacya-i-zrobiv-prigolomshlivi-znimki-yogo-poverhni-foto)

**Blue Ghost Spacecraft Captures Stunning Photos of the Moon's Surface**
The Blue Ghost spacecraft has taken photos of the surface of the Moon's southern pole during its approach to the Earth's satellite. The spacecraft is scheduled to land on the Moon's surface in early March. Blue Ghost launched its engines for four minutes and 15 seconds on February 13, putting it into an elliptical orbit around the Moon before attempting a landing. During this time, the spacecraft took several photos, which were combined into a 27-second slow-motion video. The mission is part of NASA's CLPS program, which includes 10 scientific and technical experiments. These include studying lunar dust, the radiation environment on the Moon, and the interaction between the solar wind and the Earth's magnetosphere. After landing, the spacecraft will also measure the distance to Earth using a laser reflector. The results of the experiments will help NASA better understand the lunar environment before sending astronauts to the Moon. Blue Ghost is expected to spend the next two weeks in lunar orbit, then fire its engine to make a close flyby of the Moon, and finally attempt a landing on March 2 in the Sea of Crises region. A successful landing would be historic, as only one private company, Intuitive Machines, has successfully landed a spacecraft on the Moon before, with the Odysseus spacecraft landing near the Moon's southern pole in 2024.
Original language: uk
Publish date: February 15, 2025 03:55 PM
Source:[Украинская правда](https://life.pravda.com.ua/society/yak-viglyadaye-misyac-iz-yogo-orbiti-foto-poverhni-suputnika-zrobiv-kosmichniy-aparat-blue-ghost-306455/)

**Blue Ghost Successfully Reaches Lunar Orbit—Next Stop: Mare Crisium**
The Blue Ghost lander, launched by Firefly Aerospace, has successfully reached lunar orbit, marking a major milestone in the company's mission to study the Moon's environment. The spacecraft, carrying 10 scientific experiments, will spend the next 16 days refining its orbit before attempting a historic soft landing on the Moon's surface on March 2, 2025. This mission is part of NASA's Commercial Lunar Payload Services (CLPS) program, which aims to foster private-sector involvement in space exploration. Firefly Aerospace's success with Blue Ghost could open doors to future lunar missions, including partnerships with NASA and other space agencies, and pave the way for a sustainable human presence on the Moon.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 15, 2025 02:00 PM
Source:[dailygalaxy.com](https://dailygalaxy.com/2025/02/blue-ghost-lunar-orbit-next-mare-crisium/)

**Blue Ghost captures stunning video that will make flat-earthers cringe**
The Blue Ghost lunar lander has captured a stunning video of the Earth shining in blue in the darkness of space, just five days before its historic journey to the Moon. The lander, launched on January 15, 2025, has demonstrated remarkable precision in its trajectory, allowing it to skip a planned third Earth orbit manoeuvre. The Blue Ghost mission is a significant part of Nasa's Commercial Lunar Payload Services (CLPS) initiative, aiming to deliver ten scientific payloads to Mare Crisium on the lunar surface. The lander will operate for approximately 60 days, with an expected landing date of March 2, 2025, and will capture breathtaking views of a lunar sunset before entering a dormant phase during the lunar night.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 04, 2025 06:49 AM
Source:[India Today](https://www.indiatoday.in/science/story/blue-ghost-captures-stunning-video-that-will-make-flat-earthers-cringe-moon-landing-2674494-2025-02-04)

**Moon Mission: 'Blue Ghost' and 'Resilience' Launch Successfully**
Two commercial lunar landers, 'Blue Ghost' and 'Resilience', have successfully launched from Cape Canaveral on a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket, marking the beginning of a series of moon missions. The landers are part of NASA's Commercial Lunar Payload Services (CLPS) program, which aims to collect as much knowledge as possible about the moon through private partnerships. 'Blue Ghost', developed by Firefly Aerospace, is expected to land on the moon in about 45 days, while 'Resilience', developed by ispace, is expected to land in four to five months. The mission will conduct 10 scientific experiments, including studying how to prevent dust accumulation using self-cleaning glass. 'Resilience' will also carry a small Swedish house, a typical Swedish cottage, as a piece of art. The landers will land in two different regions of the moon: 'Blue Ghost' will land in the Mare Crisium, a large impact basin, while 'Resilience' will land in the Mare Frigoris, a flat lunar sea. NASA plans to return humans to the moon by 2027, but the first manned mission has been delayed repeatedly.
Original language: de
Publish date: January 15, 2025 09:09 AM
Source:[welt.de](https://www.welt.de/wissenschaft/article255131808/Raumfahrt-Bilderbuchstart-zum-Mond.html)

**SpaceX's Falcon 9 Rocket Successfully Launches 'Blue Ghost' Lunar Lander**
SpaceX's Falcon 9 rocket successfully launched and sent the 'Blue Ghost' lunar lander from American Firefly Aerospace and the 'Hakuto-R' lunar lander from Japanese ispace to the moon. These landers will operate on different orbits and landing sites to complete their missions. According to Firefly Aerospace, the mission has been named 'Ghost Riders in the Sky'. The 'Blue Ghost Mission 1' will orbit the Earth for 25 days, then enter lunar orbit, where it will orbit the moon for 16 days before landing near the Mons Latreille mountain range in the Mare Crisium in early March 2025. The entire mission is expected to take 14 days. If everything goes as planned, 'Blue Ghost Mission 1' will begin transmitting the first batch of high-resolution images to the moon's surface. During the entire landing process, 10 NASA scientific instruments and technology demonstrations will be transmitted to help prepare for future manned moon missions. If successful, 'Blue Ghost Mission 1' will become the second mission under the CLPS program to land on the moon's surface, following the 'Odysseus' lunar lander from Intuitive Machines, which successfully landed on February 22, 2024, near the Malapert-A crater.
Original language: zh
Publish date: January 15, 2025 07:21 AM
Source:[中关村在线](https://news.zol.com.cn/939/9395637.html)

**SpaceX's Falcon 9 Rocket Successfully Launches Blue Ghost Lunar Lander**
SpaceX's Falcon 9 rocket successfully launched on January 15, carrying the 'Blue Ghost' lunar lander developed by Firefly Aerospace and the 'Hakuto-R' lunar lander developed by ispace to the Moon. The two landers will travel to different lunar orbits and landing sites using their own propulsion systems. Firefly Aerospace stated that the mission is called 'Ghost Riders in the Sky.' The Blue Ghost Mission 1 lander will orbit the Earth for 25 days before entering lunar orbit, where it will orbit the Moon for 16 days before landing near the Mons Latreille mountain range in the Mare Crisium, a large basaltic plain formed by an ancient asteroid impact. The landing is expected to take place in early March 2025. After landing, the lander will transmit high-resolution images of the Moon's surface for 14 days. The Blue Ghost mission will deploy 10 NASA scientific instruments and technology demonstrations to the Moon's surface, preparing for future lunar human missions. If successful, Blue Ghost will be the second lunar mission to land on the Moon under the CLPS program, following the Intuitive Machines' IM-1 mission's Odysseus lander, which landed on February 22, 2024.
Original language: zh
Publish date: January 15, 2025 06:58 AM
Source:[凤凰网（凤凰新媒体）](https://tech.ifeng.com/c/8gACSFtHo9M)

**iSpace's Resilience Lunar Landing Ship Successfully Launched**
Japanese private space company, iSpace, successfully launched its lunar landing ship, 'Resilience', from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida on January 15, 2025, at 1:10 AM (local time 3:10 PM). The ship is expected to reach the moon in late May and attempt to land. If successful, it will be the first achievement of a Japanese private company. iSpace previously attempted to land on the moon in April 2023, but failed. The Resilience will deploy iSpace's 'Tennessee' rover, which will collect samples of the moon's soil and rocks using a built-in scoop. iSpace has a contract with NASA to transfer ownership of the collected samples to the agency. This would be the first instance of a domestic company engaging in space resource trading. The Resilience also carries a water electrolysis device developed by Takasago Thermal Engineering, a leading air conditioning equipment manufacturer. Additionally, the launch was a joint effort with Firefly Aerospace, a US private space company, which developed the Blue Ghost lunar landing ship. This is the first time that multiple private lunar landing ships have been launched simultaneously. The Blue Ghost is expected to land on the moon in early March and follow a different trajectory than the Resilience.
Original language: ja
Publish date: January 15, 2025 06:35 AM
Source:[読売新聞オンライン](https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/science/20250115-OYT1T50116/)

**Blue Ghost, a Private U.S. Lunar Lander, Launches to the Moon**
Blue Ghost, a private U.S. lunar lander built by Firefly Aerospace, successfully launched on January 15, 2025, atop a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket. The lander, carrying 10 NASA instruments, is part of the Commercial Lunar Payload Services (CLPS) initiative, which aims to reduce the cost and increase the frequency of robotic moon missions. Blue Ghost will spend four weeks in lunar orbit before making a landing attempt in early March. The mission is a significant test for CLPS, which has had mixed results in the past. NASA hopes that CLPS will increase the frequency of robotic moon missions and save substantial money through the program. The lander's goal is to operate on the moon's surface for 14 days, including up to five hours of the long and brutally cold lunar night.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 15, 2025 06:15 AM
Source:[upstract.com](https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/blue-ghost-third-private-u-s-lunar-lander-launches-to-the-moon/?ref=upstract.com)

**Private Companies to Launch Moon Missions in 2025**
Private companies are increasingly involved in space exploration, with several companies planning to land on the Moon in 2025. Two missions, 'Blue Ghost' by Firefly and 'Resilience' by Ispace, are scheduled to launch on a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket on January 15, 2025. 'Resilience' will land on the Moon's Mare Frigoris region in four to five months, carrying a small rover and technical equipment. 'Blue Ghost' will land in the Mare Crisium region in about 45 days, carrying scientific instruments and technology demonstrations, including 10 NASA instruments. This is part of the CLPS program, which aims to create a network of companies that can transport goods to the Moon for NASA and commercial partners. Ispace has already attempted a Moon landing in April 2023, but failed. 'We will try again,' said Ispace. 'Our Hakuto-R lander will be successful this time.' 
Original language: de

Source:[Merkur.de](https://www.merkur.de/wissen/naechste-mondmissionen-vor-dem-start-spacex-rakete-soll-zwei-raumsonden-transportieren-93514529.html)

**New 'Space Race' Underway as Private Companies Push to Land on the Moon**
A new 'space race' is underway as private companies are pushing to land on the Moon. Following the success of the first private Moon landing by Intuitive Machines last year, several companies are planning to launch missions to the Moon in 2025. Two missions, 'Blue Ghost' by Firefly and 'Resilience' by Ispace, are set to launch on January 15, 2025, aboard a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket. 'Resilience' will attempt to land on the Moon's surface in April 2025, carrying a small rover and several technical instruments. Ispace's 'Hakuto-R' lander has been designed to successfully land on the Moon's surface, after a previous attempt failed in April 2023. 'Blue Ghost' is expected to land on the Moon's surface in about 45 days, carrying 10 NASA instruments and technology demonstrations. Firefly is part of NASA's CLPS program, which aims to create a network of private companies that can transport goods to the Moon for NASA and commercial partners.
Original language: de
Publish date: January 14, 2025 03:02 PM
Source:[Merkur.de](https://www.merkur.de/wissen/erneuter-ansturm-auf-mond-beginnt-spacex-rakete-soll-zwei-missionen-transportieren-nasa-93514529.html)

**Blue Ghost: A New Mission to the Moon**
SpaceX and Firefly Aerospace are set to launch the private lunar lander 'Blue Ghost' on January 15, 2025, as part of a mission to further commercialize space exploration. The lander will launch from the Kennedy Space Center's historic pad 39A on a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket at 07:11 Italian time. After 25 days in Earth orbit, Blue Ghost will enter a trajectory towards the Moon, where it will orbit for 16 days before attempting an autonomous landing in the Mare Crisium region. The lander will transmit high-definition images from the lunar surface within 30 minutes of landing, but will only have 14 days of operation before the lunar night cuts off its solar power. The mission is part of the NASA's Commercial Lunar Payload Services (CLPS) program, which aims to involve private companies in the development and transportation of scientific instruments to the Moon. Blue Ghost will carry 10 experiments and technological demonstrators, including a magnetometer, a camera system, and a dust shield. The mission is a crucial step in the commercialization of lunar exploration, following the successful landing of the Intuitive Machines' IM-1 Odysseus lander in February 2024.

The base rate for successful landings by private companies in the past few years is approximately 50%, considering the limited number of attempts and that some did achieve success, like Intuitive Machines. Applying this to the Blue Ghost mission, a private company with a planned landing date in the near future, suggests a base rate estimation of about 50% for a successful landing based on historical frequency.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Technological Advancements
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Recent advancements in space technology and the maturing of lunar landing techniques should increase the probability of success. Continuous improvement in navigation, propulsion, and landing systems based on past missions offers better outcomes. Thus, an understanding of these technological progresses should slightly enhance the success rate.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Mission Complexity
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The complexity of the Blue Ghost mission as described in available sources can impact success. Missions with higher complexity often face more risks. If this mission involves significant new systems or components, higher complexity could lower success chances, but does not drastically adjust the probability without specific derailments indicated.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Collaborations with Established Entities
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Blue Ghost's collaboration with NASA or other established space agencies and benefitting from their expertise and experience can contribute positively to mission success. The partnerships suggest an exchange of reliable technologies and best practices. This factor should bolster confidence in a successful outcome.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Launch Date Proximity
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The proximity to the planned launch and landing date during which no major delays or issues have been reported increases confidence slightly. If the mission date was postponed or if issues had emerged recently, it might decrease the probability considerably, but the absence of such issues at this time is a positive indicator.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: The news articles indicate that Blue Ghost has successfully entered lunar orbit and is preparing for its landing with all systems operating nominally. Stunning footage of both Earth and the Moon has been captured, indicating successful navigation and camera operations. The continuous updates suggest that communication with Earth remains stable and that the spacecraft has executed all necessary maneuvers correctly.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: No new reported technical challenges or unexpected issues for the mission were found in the news articles, so there's little to challenge the prior analysis conclusions.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: To determine the initial probability of the Blue Ghost successfully landing on the moon before April 1, 2025, we consider past success rates of lunar missions by private companies. Historically, lunar mission success rates vary, but recent commercial moon landings have seen improved success rates. Notably, NASA's Commercial Lunar Payload Services (CLPS) missions, which Blue Ghost is part of, indicate a focus on successful moon landings. Given the increase in overall technological sophistication and learnings from past missions, I estimate a baseline probability of 60% for successful lunar landings by companies with proven track records by their anticipated landing dates.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Technological Advancements
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Significant advancements in aerospace technology and landing systems, driven by both government and private sectors, improve mission reliability and outcomes. These advancements directly relate to the precision needed for a successful landing on the moon.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Mission Timing Buffer
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The mission's planned landing date is March 2, 2025, which leaves a margin for dealing with last-minute technical or communication challenges until the end of March. This planning buffer supports higher odds of a successful landing within the given timeframe.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Weather and External Conditions
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Space weather such as solar activity and its possible interference with communications and navigation can impact mission success. This factor slightly reduces the probability of successful landing due to its unpredictability.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Partner and Collaboration Network
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Collaboration with experienced aerospace partners, such as NASA, provides crucial support and expertise to mitigate unforeseen challenges during the mission.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Blue Ghost has successfully entered lunar orbit and completed all its preparatory maneuvers without any reported issues. The lander has captured and transmitted stunning images and video, indicating all systems are operating well. Additionally, the radiator panels are operating nominally to protect against extreme temperatures, demonstrating readiness for the lunar environment. The mission's inclusion in NASA's Commercial Lunar Payload Services program and high confidence by Firefly Aerospace reinforce the expectation of a successful landing.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: There are inherent risks in landing due to the Moon's lack of atmosphere; past commercial missions have experienced severe challenges landing, indicating a persistent risk factor. News highlights the previous failures in past missions from other companies which adds a cautious note to the high confidence placed in technology alone.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: To determine the initial probability of the Blue Ghost Mission 1 successfully landing on the moon by April 1, 2025, we can look at historical success rates of lunar landings by private companies. Historically, the success rate of missions by new private lunar lander developers is low compared to traditional government space agencies. Recent private ventures like those by SpaceX have shown varying levels of success but have increased in reliability over time. For example, the private Israeli lunar lander Beresheet crashed in 2019. The initial base rate for success will reflect a nascent private space exploration industry, estimated at around 40%.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Technological Capabilities
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Over recent years, technological advancements and increased investment in space exploration technologies have improved the capabilities of private companies. This includes advancements in avionics, landing algorithms, and materials, which makes a successful landing more likely than in earlier eras.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Experience and Track Record
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: As this is a relatively early mission for Blue Ghost, they may not have accumulated enough experience in lunar operations compared to established players. While technological advancement helps, inexperience can increase the likelihood of unforeseen issues during the landing process.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Mission Timeline
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Given that this mission specifically aims for a landing by March 2, 2025, there might be little room for delays or corrections post any complications, thus keeping risk factors high if initial operations face issues.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Preliminary Testing and Demonstrations
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: If Blue Ghost conducted rigorous prior tests and had successful demonstrations, this could increase their chance of success. However, if such tests have been insufficient or have shown irregularities, it may indicate increased risk.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Several news articles mention the successful completion of Blue Ghost's elliptical and lunar orbital maneuvers, indicating that the spacecraft systems are functioning well, which bodes well for a successful landing. Additionally, the capture of stunning lunar footage and the spacecraft's healthy payload status as it nears its landing date suggest operational readiness. The historic success of the previous Intuitive Machines' landing provides confidence in private lunar landing capabilities.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: Landing on the Moon remains a challenging task, as indicated by mixed results in recent private lunar landings. The mission still faces the risk of unforeseen technical challenges during the landing process, given its ambitious goals and the inherent difficulty of lunar landings due to the lack of atmosphere and precise navigation requirements.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: Historically, the success rate of lunar landings in the context of recent private and national space missions provides a base rate. Given the relatively high success rates of lunar landings by organizations like NASA in recent decades, as well as the increasing competence of private space companies, a reasonable base rate for a successful lunar landing attempt stands around 70%. The recent advancements in technology and improved mission planning contribute significantly to this high base rate.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Development Track Record of Blue Ghost
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The technical expertise and the track record of the team behind Blue Ghost are important. If they have previously demonstrated successful launches or landings, it would increase confidence in this attempt.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Weather and Space Conditions
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Adverse weather conditions or unexpected space weather events can impact the success of space missions. However, given the robust planning and predictions available, such effects often have mitigated impacts. Still, they pose some level of risk.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Current Technological Environment
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Innovations and technology advancements in lunar landing vehicles have significantly improved outcomes for mission success. Recent trends in space technology have increased the reliability of missions.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Time Constraints
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The closeness of the target date (March 2, 2025) means that any technical issues have a reduced window for resolution. This could introduce an element of risk if any unforeseen issues arise close to the landing date.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Blue Ghost has successfully captured and transmitted images and videos from lunar orbit, demonstrating its systems' operational readiness and communication capabilities. Firefly Aerospace's history of managing the spacecraft's trajectory and entering lunar orbit successfully reinforces confidence in mission execution. The spacecraft has completed all pre-landing maneuvers and has posted nominal operations of subsystems, including radiator panels critical for thermal management.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: While pre-landing operations appear successful, the actual lunar landing remains a challenging procedure due to the Moon's lack of atmosphere and previous failures in private lunar missions, such as ispace's Hakuto-R lander in 2023 and Astrobotic's mission in 2024. These factors introduce a degree of uncertainty surrounding the final landing phase.

summary: After two phases of analysis, experts have revised their predictions for the successful landing of the Blue Ghost mission on the moon before April 1, 2025. Initial probabilities varied among experts, ranging from 40% to 85%, based on historical success rates, technological advancements, and the experience of private companies in lunar missions. Factors such as technological maturity, tight schedules, and the involvement of NASA's CLPS program were highlighted. In phase 2, news articles reported successful orbital maneuvers, system operations, and mission preparations, reinforcing confidence in the mission. However, experts acknowledged the inherent risks of lunar landings, including the lack of atmosphere and historical challenges. Revised probabilities increased slightly, with most experts converging around a 70-90% likelihood of success. The consensus reflects cautious optimism, balancing recent positive developments with the remaining uncertainties of the landing phase.
